docs.lead_paragraph: Eat some food before flying, but not too much on Thanksgiving. Take vitamin B3 with cholesterol-reducing drugs. Sporadic exercise may be hazardous to your health. Aggressive treatment of mild heart attacks saves lives. Those are some of the messages offered by researchers last week at the annual scientific meeting of the American Heart Association in New Orleans.

headline.main: Aggressive Approaches Can Bolster Heart Health

docs.abstract: Two studies reported at American Heart Association meeting in New Orleans strongly suggest that early, aggressive treatment for even minor heart attacks cuts down on future problems; other researchers report that a particularly heavy meal roughly quadruples the risk of heart attack the first two hours after eating, that people who snack and drink nonalcoholic liquids before boarding a plane are at less risk of fainting and heart attacks, that a three-minute test to measure cholesterol levels in the outer layer of skin may offer a new way of measuring the risk of heart disease, that infrequent exercisers are more likely to suffer heart attacks while working out than those who exercise more frequently and that health clubs do not do a good job preparing their staffs to help a member who suffers a heart attack (M)
docs.snippet: Eat some food before flying, but not too much on Thanksgiving. Take vitamin B3 with cholesterol-reducing drugs. Sporadic exercise may be hazardous to your health. Aggressive treatment of mild heart attacks saves lives.    Those are some of the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many people are all too familiar with this condition: It starts with a cold that lingers well beyond the 7 to 10 days colds usually last, leaving a person feeling stuffed up, dragged out, headachy and irritable. Or perhaps it begins with a spring or fall allergy, but long after the person is no longer exposed to pollen or mold spores, discomforting respiratory symptoms persist. It is in all likelihood a sinus infection -- sinusitis in medical parlance, an ailment that afflicts an about 37 million Americans each year, that is now soaring in prevalence and that is the fifth most common reason for which antibiotics are prescribed. But, experts say, in many cases that prescription is inappropriate and ill-advised, and this misuse of antibiotics is contributing to a growing medical crisis: antibiotic resistance among common bacterial causes of respiratory infections.

headline.main: Coping With a 'Cold' That Stays Too Long

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody column on sinusitis, an infection of the sinuses that affects about 37 million Americans each year and that is often inappropriately treated with antibiotics; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: As a child in the Netherlands, Rebecca Gomperts often sailed with her family in the chilly waters of the North Sea, a pastime that left her with a seemingly fearless attraction to things nautical. Today, as a 34-year-old gynecologist and public health advocate, Dr. Gomperts hopes to brave the elements again, this time to offer abortions and other reproductive services 12 miles offshore to women who cannot obtain them legally at home. Her goal and that of her Amsterdam-based group, the Women on Waves Foundation, is not only to help individual women but to publicize a public health issue that remains taboo in many parts of the world, despite estimates ranging from 60,000 to 100,000 deaths a year from unsafe abortions.

headline.main: Doctor Plans Off-Shore Clinic for Abortions

docs.abstract: Dr Rebecca Gomperts and her Amsterdam-based group, Women on Waves Foundation, are raising funds to charter a Dutch ship to offer abortions and other reproductive services 12 miles off the shore of countries that bar abortions; Netherlands' liberal abortion laws would prevail in international waters; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A year ago, Laurie Melzak-Klein, a 29-year-old social worker in Manalapan, N.J., was pregnant with her first child. She was carrying a boy, tests had shown, and he seemed perfectly healthy. But at 20 weeks, her obstetrician told her and her husband, Bryan Klein, that their son could not survive. Ms. Melzak-Klein was bound to lose the pregnancy, he said, and should terminate it.
docs.abstract: Doctors at New York University Medical Center seal womb of pregnant woman that did not heal after amniocentesis; rupture allowed amniotic fluid to leak out of the womb and prompted mother's obstetrician to tell her that fetus could not survive; a healthy baby is later delivered by Caesarian section; photo (M)
